| UEFAu21Champ apps = 16 | UEFAu21Champ first = [[UEFA U-21 Championship 1978|1978]] | UEFAu21Champ best = Winners: [[UEFA U-21 Championship 1992|1992]], [[UEFA U-21 Championship 1994|1994]],
[[UEFA U-21 Championship 1996|1996]], [[UEFA U-21 Championship 2000|2000]], [[UEFA U-21 Championship 2004|2004]] | }} The '''Italy national under-21 football team''' is the national under-21 [[Association football|football]] team of [[Italy]] and is controlled by the [[Italian Football Federation]]. The team competes in the [[UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship]], held every two years. Italy is the most successful nation in the history of the competition, with five Championships won ([[1992 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1992]], [[1994 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1994]], [[1996 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1996]], [[2000 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2000]] and [[2004 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2004]]). Following the realignment of [[UEFA]]'s youth competitions in 1976, the Italian Under-21 team was formed. Until 1990, the team had a very good record - reaching the last eight of each of the first seven UEFA U-21 Championships. From 1990 to 2004 the team established near-total dominance of European Under-21 football, winning five of the seven tournaments. The lowest point for the team came in 1997, when it failed to qualify for the 1998 finals. The team won the 2000 tournament finals in Slovakia and the [[2004 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2004]] tournament finals in [[Germany]]. In the [[2006 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2006]] tournament finals in [[Portugal]] the team failed to advance to second round. This was Italy's 14th U-21 finals tournament. Italy's Under-21s played the first match at the new [[Wembley Stadium]], on 24 March 2007, against [[England national under-21 football team|England Under-21s]]. The game resulted in a 3-3 draw, with [[Giampaolo Pazzini]] scoring all 3 goals for the Azzurrini. Prior to the 2008 Olympic games, Italy U-21s went on to win the [[2008 Toulon Tournament]] by beating Chile (1-0) in the final. It was the first time they had won this tournament, previously their best had been runner-up on two occasions[http://www.channel4.com/sport/football_italia/may30a.html channel4.com - Football Italia]. In the [[2009 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2009 U-21 Championship]] Italy was eliminated in the semi-finals. == UEFA U-23 Championship Record == Since the under-21 competition rules insist that players must be 21 or under at the start of a two year competition, technically it is an U-23 competition. For this reason, Italy's record in the preceding U-23 competitions is also shown. * 1972: ''Did not qualify. Finished 2nd of 3 in qualification group.'' * 1974: Losing quarter-finalists. * 1976: ''Did not qualify. Finished 2nd of 3 in qualification group.'' == UEFA U-21 Championship Record == * [[1978 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1978]]: Losing quarter-finalists. * [[1980 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1980]]: Losing quarter-finalists. * [[1982 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1982]]: Losing quarter-finalists. * [[1984 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1984]]: Losing semi-finalists. * [[1986 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1986]]: Runners-up. * [[1988 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1988]]: Losing quarter-finalists. * [[1990 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1990]]: Losing semi-finalists. * [[1992 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1992]]: '''Winners'''. * [[1994 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1994]]: '''Winners'''. * [[1996 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1996]]: '''Winners'''. * [[1998 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|1998]]: ''Did not qualify''. * [[2000 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2000]]: '''Winners'''. * [[2002 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2002]]: Losing semi-finalists. * [[2004 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2004]]: '''Winners'''. * [[2006 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2006]]: Finished 3rd of 4 in finals group. * [[2007 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2007]]: Finished 3rd of 4 in finals group; Winner of the Olympic qualification play-off. * [[2009 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2009]]: Losing semi-finalists. * [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2011]]: ''Did not qualify''. ==Olympics football Record== {{MedalTop}} {{MedalSport | Men's [[Football at the Summer Olympics|Football]]}} {{MedalBronze | [[2004 Summer Olympics|2004 Athens]] | [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Team]]}} {{MedalBottom}} Since 1992 Olympics football changed to U-23 event, and the European U-21 teams, technically is a U-23 teams. The winner, runner-up and third place of UEFA U-21 Championship qualify for Olympics. *Before 1992: ''See [[Italy national football team]]'' *[[Football at the 1992 Summer Olympics|1992]]: Losing quarter-finalists *[[Football at the 1996 Summer Olympics|1996]]: Finished 4th of 4 in finals group *[[Football at the 2000 Summer Olympics|2000]]: Losing quarter-finalists *[[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics|2004]]: Bronze Medal *[[Football at the 2008 Summer Olympics|2008]]: Losing quarter-finalists *[[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics|2012]]: ''Did not qualify'' ==Mediterranean Games Record== Mediterranean Games Football tournament was U-23 event in 1993 and 1997. *1993: 4th place *1997: '''Winners''' *2001: ''a U20 event'' *2005: ''filled with B team'' ==Coaches== *1976â1986: [[Azeglio Vicini]] *1986â1996: [[Cesare Maldini]] *1996â1998: [[Rossano Giampaglia]] *1998â2000: [[Marco Tardelli]] *2000â2006: [[Claudio Gentile]] *2006â2010: [[Pierluigi Casiraghi]] *2010âpresent: [[Ciro Ferrara]] ==Current players== Players born in [[1990]] or later are eligible for the [[2013 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship]]. {| width=100% |valign="top" width=20%| '''1990-born'''
